newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds end stronger, outperform as dlr gains.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds end stronger, outperform as dlr gains.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed stronger on Friday, outperforming their U.S. counterparts, following a sharp rally in the Canadian dollar and continued speculation the Bank of Canada will cut interest rates, analysts said.

"The dollar firmed, so that helped and there is some belief that as the dollar firms, the greater the chance of the Bank of Canada easing," said Michael Gregory, an economist and strategist with Lehman Brothers.
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.25 at C$103.40 to yield 7.697 percent against the U.S. 30-year benchmark which fell 9/32 to yield 6.91 percent.
The spread between the two benchmark bonds narrowed to 79 basis points from 83 basis points at the close of trading on Thursday.

The Canadian dollar closed stronger at C$1.3627 (US$0.7339) in very heavy trading from Thursday's close at C$1.3676 (US$0.7312). The gains came as the unit broke through a key technical level at C1.3650, dealers said.

Canadian bonds had rallied earlier in the session on the back of gains in U.S. fixed-income markets. But Canadian bonds held onto gains as the U.S. market weakened amid profit-taking and a new issue by Ford Motor of US$500 million in notes.
In other prices, the 7.0 percent of 2006 rose C$0.12 to C$98.96 to yield 7.144 percent. The U.S. 10-year benchmark fell 4/32 to yield 6.68 percent.
The spread between the two benchmark bonds narrowed to 46 basis points from 50 basis points at Thursday's close.
The three-month cash bill traded at 3.87 percent against the U.S. three-month bill at 5.03 percent.
